title: How Jorginho has reinvented himself as Frank Lampard’s Chelsea ‘driver’
text:
Jorginho has been an integral part of Chelsea’s side under Frank Lampard (Picture: Getty)

In a parallel universe, Tammy Abraham, Mason Mount and Fikayo Tomori are all on loan somewhere, Frank Lampard is still a Championship manager and an expensively assembled Chelsea squad are still looking to adapt in a post-Eden Hazard-era at Stamford Bridge.

Watching Lampard’s carefree Chelsea side with youth academy products populating key positions grow in confidence in recent weeks, it has been easy to speculate how different things might have been had FIFA not banned the club from buying anyone for 12 months.

Along with Lampard and the youngsters, Jorginho’s path might have taken a different route in the summer had Chelsea’s transfer ban been delayed or reversed. Maurizio Sarri would have left regardless but a more high-profile manager than Lampard would likely have been appointed.

Whether someone like Max Allegri would have wanted to keep a player who symbolised more than anyone else Chelsea’s ‘Sarriball’ style in 2018-19 is open to debate. New managers often assert their authority by ostracising or offloading influential players from the previous regime. Lampard, though, didn’t have a choice.

Advertisement

Advertisement

There were murmurings that Sarri wanted to whisk the centrepiece of his Napoli and Chelsea teams off to Turin, but those rumours didn’t appear to have much substance. Having been booed by Chelsea fans in February, Jorginho elected to stay put to prove them wrong this season. So far, so good.

First impressions

Frank Lampard was impressed with Jorginho’s dedication in training during Chelsea’s pre-season (Picture: Getty)

Lampard had plenty on his plate during a chaotic first year in management with Derby County but given his 13-year association with Chelsea as a player, he will undoubtedly have kept a keen eye on their performances under Sarri.

Perhaps Lampard had his own preconceptions of Jorginho based upon what he had seen and heard from afar, but it didn’t take long to convince him that the 27-year-old was one of the few Sarri favourites worth keeping around as part of a new-look Chelsea.

‘He’s a voice. He runs, he pushes people around him, he drags people up when he doesn’t feel they’re working as much as he might want,’ Lampard said in July. ‘I’ve loved seeing that. So in terms of first impressions, working with him for 10 days, I can’t ask for any more. I’m delighted to have him.’

Those positive early impressions have clearly stuck. Only three players – goalkeeper Kepa Arrizabalaga, Cesar Azpilicueta and Mason Mount – have played more Premier League minutes for Chelsea this season than Jorginho, who along with that trio has started every game so far.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Regardless of whether Lampard has played a 4-3-3, 3-4-2-1 or 4-2-3-1 formation, Jorginho has started in central midfield every time. Just as with Sarri last season, Jorginho is one of the first names on the teamsheet but his role has been tweaked under Lampard.

Greater freedom

Frank Lampard has encouraged Jorginho to play with greater freedom at Chelsea this season (Picture: Getty)

Chelsea under Sarri were a team renowned for their possession-orientated style, having on average 60 per cent of the ball in the Premier League last season – a total only bettered by Manchester City who had 64 per cent. Jorginho was fundamental to that, attempting more passes than any other player in the division.

A frequent criticism of Sarri and by association Jorginho was that Chelsea were passing for passing sake. Too often there wasn’t enough penetration and Lampard has attempted to rectify that by quickening up Chelsea’s build-up play and encouraging his midfielders to look forward earlier.

Although Chelsea still averages more possession than their opponents, their focus has switched from attempting to drag opponents out of position through patient ball retention to looking to counter on them quickly by sending passes forward with greater urgency.

After seven games, Chelsea’s possession rate has dropped to 54 per cent, lower than six other clubs in the Premier League. Jorginho’s passes per game rate also demonstrates the shift in style, as he has gone from attempting 84.3 passes per game to 66.9 this season.

Advertisement

Despite playing just under 20 fewer passes on average, though, Jorginho’s percentage success rate is down to 85 per cent from 89 per cent last season which coupled with his average number of key passes increasing from 0.8 to 1.3 each match, highlights his more expansive role in the side.

Jorginho already has one league assist to his name in 2019-20 compared to none in 2018-19 and last month he admitted that Lampard has given him more ‘freedom’ in his play by asking him to play higher up the pitch.

He expanded on that ahead of the game against Lille on Wednesday, saying: ‘He [Lampard] wants more forward play, not too much short passing, so I am trying to do that. This season we are playing with more long balls, more runs, less short passing.’

Coping without Kante

N’Golo Kante returned alongside Jorginho during Wednesday’s match against Lille (Picture: Getty)

Although Jorginho has provided greater attacking impetus from midfield, he has also had to get through a lot of defensive work too, due largely to the injury-enforced absence of N’Golo Kante for much of the season.

Kante’s superhuman levels of endurance have been discussed at length during his four and a bit years in English football but having played virtually without rest for club and country since 2016, even he has shown signs of wear and tear recently.

The Frenchman has missed seven games in the Premier League or Champions League since May, as many as he had missed through injury during his first two seasons with Chelsea. Without Kante nor a natural replacement, Jorginho has had to help plug the gap.

Advertisement

Jorginho has made the most tackles (18), interceptions (16) and recoveries (62) in Chelsea’s squad during their opening Premier League fixtures. He has also out-performed Liverpool and Manchester City’s midfield screeners Fabinho and Rodri in each of those metrics too.

Opta definition of 'Recovery' This is where a player recovers the ball in a situation where neither team has possession or where the ball has been played directly to him by an opponent, thus securing possession for their team.

Those stats, allied to Jorginho’s impressive passing numbers and improved influence in the final third, paint a picture of an all-action man in the middle for Chelsea. His contribution has been vital and with Kante coming through unscathed against Lille on Wednesday, they can provide an exceptionally stable base from which Mount, Abraham and Willian can benefit.

Changing perceptions

Jorginho has got Chelsea fans back onside with his performances at the start of the season (Picture: Getty)

From being booed in February to being sung about in September. Jorginho’s redemption arc was completed when Chelsea supporters chanted his name during the 3-2 victory over Norwich City at Carrow Road in August.

Lampard admitted he was ‘delighted’ with the reaction of the fans, saying: ‘He’s just a fantastic sportsman who cares deeply. When you have a training session that might fall below standard or drop for a moment, he’s the one who drives it up again.

‘When the fans see that on the pitch, as they did at Norwich, that’s why they sing his name. I’m delighted with that.’

From Sarri’s star pupil to the leader of Lampard’s revolution, Jorginho has capitalised on Chelsea’s transfer ban by reinventing himself at Stamford Bridge.

It has been the year of the academy stars at Stamford Bridge but Jorginho is the ticking heartbeat of this exciting new team.
